minor.description: easily able to read through (e.g. incorrect capitalisation, pronouns/prepositions, omission of secondary detail)

standard.description: disrupts the flow and comprehension (e.g. misrecognized/omitted names, homophones/sound-alikes, omission of primary detail)

serious.description: misinformation which changes meaning (e.g. alternative names/numbers, incorrect word endings/contractions, omission causing misinformation)

examples.reference: Um, um, yes I am um very happy to see you Ra'Shede Hageman, bye.
examples.recognised: Um, yes I am very happy to see you Rash eared haggard man.
examples.reason: misrecognized name "Ra'Shede Hageman" as "Rash eared haggard man" (standard), "bye" is omitted (standard)

examples.reference: This has been confirmed by the Pentagon and an executive will call you.
examples.recognised: This hasn't been confirmed by the Pentagon and in executive will call you.
examples.reason: "has" contraction reversed to "hasn't" causing misinformation (serious), "an" misrecognized as "in" but easy to read through (minor)

examples.reference: I laughed and cried twenty times but it turned out okay.
examples.recognised: I laughed and cried, perhaps too much of the latter, 20 times but it turned out ok.
examples.reason: "perhaps too much of the latter" has been inserted but makes sense (minor)

examples.reference: Hi my name is Bob and I like cheese a lot.
examples.recognised: Hi my frame is fob and I bike cheeses lot.
examples.reason: "name" misrecognized as "frame" (serious), "Bob" misrecognized as "fob" (standard), "like" misrecognized as "bike" (standard), "cheese" recognized as "cheeses" (minor), "a" is missed out (minor)
